Alright, I'll be the bad guy. I'll be the jerk who says the D-word, if no one else will: Singapore is essentially *a dictatorship.* That's what you call a state without opposition parties that stand a realistic chance of taking power from the reigning party. That's the secret as to why public works in Singapore are not shot down by NIMBY, the way they constantly are in other countries. We in the West tend to view government that operate this way as universally bad. Because during the early/mid 20'th century, we had some very, very times under such governments. And because many people living under such governments today, are still having a bad time of it. 
Please understand that I am by no means advocating for running things the way Singapore does, as there are serious risks involved, but: Singapore shows that a dictatorship need not be a totalitarian regime that rules against the will of it's people. As I understand it, people in Singapore could _theoretically_ just elect another party into power if they truly wanted to. The ruling party just enjoys enough support from the people, that that never actually happens. 
The elections in Singapore are more referenda than they are transfers of power; If the ruling party does something the people don't like or isn't taking things in the right direction ‚Äî The people vote for the opposition parties in greater numbers than normal, to let the ruling party know it screwed up somewhere. And the ruling party - apparently - takes these protest votes to heart. The corrective function of democracy remains intact, despite the lack of any transfers of power.
